program atcoder_ABC168_B
  implicit none
  integer :: K
  character(len=1000) :: S

  N = len_trim(S)
  if (N <= K) then

program atcoder_ABC168_B
  implicit none
  integer :: K
  character(len=1000) :: S

  read(*,*) K, S
  if (len_trim(S) <= K) then
    write(*,*) S
  else
    write(*,*) S(1:K) // '...'
  end if
end program atcoder_ABC168_B

What if the string has trailing spaces? Well, according to the read behavior, when using list-directed read, the trailing spaces are NOT part of the string. Because when reading a character variable with list-directed input, it reads the next token, so any trailing spaces in the input are not part of the token? Or are they considered?

Wait, let me clarify how list-directed input works for character variables.

In list-directed input, when reading a character variable, the input record is scanned for the next character string (non-whitespace sequence), which is assigned to the variable. The trailing spaces are NOT part of the character sequence. Hence, if the input has spaces after S, they are not part of S.

Therefore, the LEN_TRIM(S) is exactly the length of the input string S.

Thus the code is safe.

Therefore this should work.
